questions.text: During starvation, body mainly utilizes fatty acid oxidation as major energy generating process. The breakdown of one molecule of a C16 fully saturated fatty acid (palmitic acid) by β-oxidation lead to the formation of:
questions.solution:
The breakdown of palmitic acid (C16) requires 7 cycles of βoxidation each producing 1 FADH2 and 1 NADH molecule and results in the formation of eight 2C acetyl CoA molecules.

In the β-oxidation pathway, two carbons at a time are cleaved from acyl-CoA molecules, starting at the carboxyl end. The chain is broken between the α(2)- and β(3)- carbon atoms—hence the name β-oxidation. The two-carbon units formed are acetyl-CoA; thus, palmitoyl-CoA forms eight acetyl-CoA molecules.

“Fatty acid oxidase,” are found in the mitochondrial matrix or inner membrane adjacent to the respiratory chain. These catalyze the oxidation of acyl-CoA to acetyl-CoA via the β-oxidation pathway. In the process, large quantities of the reducing equivalents FADH2 and NADH are generated and are used to form ATP by oxidative phosphorylation.

questions.text: All of the following grow and reproduce, EXCEPT:

choices.text: blood-forming cells of the bone marrow

questions.solution: Some cells grow and reproduce all the time, such as the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow, the germinal layers of the skin, and the epithelium of the gut. Many other cells, however, such as smooth muscle cells, may not reproduce for many years. A few cells, such as the neurons and most striated muscle cells, do not reproduce during the entire life of a person, except during the original period of fetal life.

questions.text: Aspirin exerts its effects by reducing the production of prostaglandins and thromboxanes from arachidonic acid. This effect is mediated by inhibition of which of the following enzymes by aspirin?
questions.solution:
Aspirin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that inhibits COX-1 and COX- 2. Other NSAIDs include indomethacin and ibuprofen, and these usually inhibit cyclooxygenases by competing with arachidonate.

Prostanoid synthesis involves the consumption of two molecules of O2 catalyzed by cyclooxygenase (COX) (also called prostaglandin H synthase), an enzyme that has two activities, a cyclooxygenase and peroxidase.

COX is present as two isoenzymes, COX-1 and COX-2. The product, an endoperoxide (PGH), is converted to prostaglandins D and E as well as to a thromboxane (TXA2 ) and prostacyclin (PGI2 ). Each cell type produces only one type of prostanoid. The NSAID aspirin inhibits COX-1 and COX-2. Other NSAIDs include indomethacin and ibuprofen, and usually inhibit cyclooxygenases by competing with arachidonate. Since inhibition of COX-1 causes the stomach irritation often associated with taking NSAIDs, attempts have been made to develop drugs which selectively inhibit COX-2 (coxibs).

questions.text: A 17-year-old adolescent girl presented at clinic with bruises on her lower extremities. Of the following, which is least likely to explain the bleeding signs exhibited by this individual?
questions.solution:
Hemophilia A, being an X-chromosome–linked disease, is a very unlikely to occur in a female.

Hemophilia is a sex-linked recessive disorder. The abnormal gene responsible for hemophilia is carried on the X chromosome. Males have one X chromosome and one Y chromosome. In a male, the presence of the abnormal gene results in the deficiency or absence of factor VIII or factor IX, as there is no protective X to make factor VIII or IX. Affected males cannot transmit the abnormal gene to their sons who inherit a Y chromosome from their father. However, all daughters of a man with hemophilia are considered obligate carriers of hemophilia because they must receive the affected X chromosome from their fathers to be female, and they can pass the gene to their sons.

A female with the hemophilia gene is called a hemophilia carrier. Females have two X chromosomes, so the presence of the hemophilia gene on one X does not result in hemophilia. The presence of the normal gene that codes for the production of factor compensates for the defective gene that does not. While usually not affected, females who have the gene can pass the gene to a son who will have hemophilia. In some cases, female carriers can have bleeding symptoms. A woman is also considered an obligate carrier if she has more than one son with hemophilia, and they have at least one son and one other relative with hemophilia.

questions.text: In the rhodopsin-retinal visual cycle in the rod, there is re-formation of rhodopsin wherein all-trans retinal is converted into?
questions.solution: The first stage in re-formation of rhodopsin, as shown in Figure, is to reconvert the all-- trans retinal into 11-cis retinal. This process requires metabolic energy and is catalyzed by the enzyme retinal isomerase. Once the 11-cis retinal is formed, it automatically recombines with the scotopsin to re-- form rhodopsin, which then remains stable until its decomposition is again triggered by absorption of light energy.

questions.text: The slow-chronic paleospinothalamic pathway terminates in all of the areas except:

choices.text: the reticular nuclei of the medulla, pons, and mesencephalon
the anterior thalamic nuclei to the habenula
the tectal area of the mesencephalon deep to the superior and inferior colliculi
the periaqueductal gray region surrounding the aqueduct of Sylvius.

questions.solution: The slow-chronic paleospinothalamic pathway terminates widely in the brain stem. Only 10% to 25% of the fibers pass all the way to the thalamus. Instead, most terminate in one of three areas: (1) the reticular nuclei of the medulla, pons, and mesencephalon; (2) the tectal area of the mesencephalon deep to the superior and inferior colliculi; or (3) the periaqueductal gray region surrounding the aqueduct of Sylvius. These lower regions of the brain appear to be important for feeling the suffering types of pain. From the brain stem pain areas, multiple short-fiber neurons relay the pain signals upward into the intralaminar and ventrolateral nuclei of the thalamus and into certain portions of the hypothalamus and other basal regions of the brain

questions.text: An 10-year-old boy is brought to a physician with complaints of developmental delays, a gradual lowering of IQ and worsening vision. Physical examination reveals a downward and inward dislocation of the lens, long and thin extremities with low muscle tone. The physician informs them that the boy is at increased risk for thromboembolic events. What is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The boy is showing most of the symptoms of homocystinuria, such as progressive intellectual disability, marfanoid habitus (tall and thin, elongated limbs, scoliosis), and subluxation of the ocular lens (ectopia lentis), that can be further confirmed by checking the homocysteine levels in blood and urine. Homocystinuria is an inborn error of methionine metabolism. Homocysteine can combine with serine to form cystathionine; this reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme cystathionine synthase. The autosomal recessive mutation of this enzyme results in the accumulation of homocysteine and the many manifestations of homocystinuria.

Infants with homocystinuria are normal at birth. Clinical manifestations during infancy are nonspecific and may include failure to thrive and developmental delay.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are CORRECT?

The Lesch-Nyhan syndrome reflects a defect in hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase.
Metabolic disorders are only infrequently associated with defects in the catabolism of purines.
Xanthine lithiasis can be due to a severe defect in xanthine oxidase.
Hyperuricemia can result from conditions such as cancer characterized by enhanced tissue turnover.
questions.solution:
Metabolic disorders are infrequently associated with defects in pyrimidine catabolism (Not purine catabolism), which forms water-soluble products.

Unlike the low solubility products of purine catabolism, catabolism of the pyrimidines forms highly water- soluble products— CO2 , NH3 , β-alanine, and β-aminoisobutyrate.

Few infrequent metabolic disorders that are associated with pyrimidine metabolism:

Enzyme Defect Features
Dihydropyrimidine Dehydrogenase Toxicity to 5-Fluorouracil
Orotate Phosphoribosyl transferase + Orotidylic acid decarboxylase Orotic aciduria Type I and Megaloblastic anemia
Orotidylic acid decarboxylase Orotic aciduria Type II

questions.text: Cardiac sympathetic denervation generally refers to interrupting the sympathetic input to the heart by removing or blocking the extrinsic sympathetic nerves. This is done pre transplantation of the heart. What changes in his heart ratee are observed in a patient with heart transplant?
questions.solution: The sino-atrial node displays intrinsic automaticity at a rate of 100-110bpm. This rhythm is influenced by sympathetic vagal nerves resulting in a ‘vagal tone’ at rest, thus reducing the resting heart rate down to 60-80bpm. Cardiac sympathetic denervation of the right vagus leads to an abrupt increase in the SA Nodal firing rate resulting in an increased heart rate upto 80-100bpm.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is NOT CORRECT?

choices.text: If the pKa of a weak acid is 4.0, 50% of the molecules will be in the dissociated state when the pH of the surrounding environment is 4.0.
A weak acid with a pKa of 4.0 will be a more effective buffer at pH 3.8 than at pH 5.7.
At a pH equal to its pI, a polypeptide carries no charged groups.
The pKa of an ionizable group can be influenced by the physical and chemical properties of its surrounding environment.

questions.solution:
Ka is the dissociation constant of an acid. Ka = [HA+] [A-] /[HA]. pKa is the negative logarithm of Ka. Stronger the acid is lesser the pKa is. At its pKa, an acid will be half dissociated means half of the total number of molecules will be in ionized form (Option 1 is true)

Generally, a combination of weak acid and its base is used as a buffer. The capacity of a buffer is highest in the region of pKa ± 1. For a pKa of 4 the effective buffer range is 3-5 (Option 2 is true).

Amino acids has more than one dissociable group, so thay have multiple pKa values. e.g. Lysine has 3 ionisable groups i.e. alpha amino(Pk2), alpha carboxyl(PK1) and epsilon amino(pK3). The numbering is based on the order of dissociation. Alpha carboxyl group is more acidic compared to the other groups and dissociates first. pKa of these groups are influenced by the neighboring atoms and groups in the amino acid structure (Option 4 is true)

At its pI, an amino acid has an equal number of positive and negative charges, but has no net overall charge (Option 3 is false)

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true in regard to glucuronidation reactions?

choices.text: Include the enzymatic activity of alcohol dehydrogenase
Require an active center as the site of conjugation

questions.solution: Glucuronidation reactions, which are considered phase II reactions, require an active center (a functional group) as the site of conjugation. Phase I reactions are biotransformation reactions, not conjugation reactions. Alcohol dehydrogenase is an example of a phase I reaction. Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) is required for aromatic hydroxylation, an example of a phase I reaction.

questions.text: A male, middle-aged chronic smoker presents with painful lesions over his limbs, complaints of intermittent claudication and rest pain. He has had pain in his extremities for about a year now. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Thromboangiitis obliterans is characterized by segmental, thrombosing, acute and chronic inflammation of mediumand small-sized arteries, especially the tibial and radial arteries, that often leads to vascular insufficiency, typically of the extremities. It occurs almost exclusively in heavy cigarette smokers, usually before the age of 35. Early manifestations include Raynaud phenomenon, instep foot pain induced by exercise (instep claudication), and a superficial nodular phlebitis (venous inflammation). The vascular insufficiency of Buerger disease tends to be accompanied by severe pain—even at rest – due to neural involvement.

questions.text: A 17-year-old develops Neisseria meningitidis meningitis. What was the first event?

choices.text: CNS invasion directly through cribriform plate

questions.solution: Neisseria meningitidis is transmitted by direct oral mucosal contact or direct receipt of infected respiratory droplets on another’s oropharyngeal mucosa. Nm adheres via pili and other adhesins; additionally, IgA-protease production and the capsule allow survival in a non-immune individual, allowing upper respiratory colonization that is followed by invasion of the bloodstream. This precedes development of pneumonia or meningitis. Skin lesions develop from overproduction of outer membrane, which is excreted without being incorporated, causing endotoxic shock and petechiae that progress to frank purpura. Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome is late.

questions.text: An old man with hypertension and BP 210/110 mm Hg is classified as having Severe hypertension. Which type of scale is used here?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ordinal

  • In the given question,
    • If BP is measured as absolute quantified numbers (E.g., BP 210/110), it should be measured on a Metric scale.
    • If BP is categorized as Mild-Moderate-Severe, it will become the Ordinal scale.
  • The ordinal scale is based on ORD (order): Grading into categories
  • Examples: TNM staging (cancers), Severity of disease, Social classes.

Option A: Nominal

  • Based on NOM (names): No specific order.
  • Examples: Race, Religion, Country of birth, Clinical features, Sites of lymphadenopathy, Sex of child, Type of anemia, ABO blood group, Site of malignancy.

Option C: Interval

  • Interval scale (Absence of absolute zero; no ratios possible).
  • Examples: Centigrade/ Fahrenheit temperature scale.

Option D: Ratio

  • Ratio scale (Presence of absolute zero; thus ratios are possible).
  • Examples: Weight, Height, Blood glucose, Hemoglobin level, Serum cholesterol, Mid-arm circumference, Blood pressure, Pulse rate, and Kelvin temperature scale.

questions.text: In school health service, one latrine should be provided for:
questions.solution:
School Environment

Site : The site should be on suitable high land, and not subject to inundation or dampness and can be properly drained. The School Health Committee (1961) had recommended that 10 acres of land be provided for higher elementary schools and 5 acres for primary schools with an additional one acre of land per 100 students. In congested areas, the nearest public park or playground should be made available to the students.

Structure : Nursery and secondary schools, as far as possible, be single storied. Exterior walls should have a minimum thickness of 10 inches and should be heat resistant.

Classroom :No classroom should accommodate more than 40 students. Per capita space for students in a classroom should not be less than 10 sq. ft.

Furniture : Furniture should suit the age group of students. It is desirable to provide single desks and chairs.Desks should be of "minus" type. Chairs should be provided with proper back-rests, with facilities for desk-work.

Doors and windows: The windows should be broad with the bottom sill, at a height of 2'-6" from the floor level; combined door and window area should be at least 25 per cent of the floor space; windows should be placed on different walls for cross-ventilation; the ventilators should not be less than 2 per cent of the floor area.

Color : Inside color of the classroom should be white and should be periodically white-washed.

Lighting : Classrooms should have sufficient natural light, preferably from the left,and should not be from the front.

Water supply: There should be an independent source of safe and potable water supply, which should be continuous, and distributed from the taps.

Eating facilities : Vendors other than those approved by the school authorities should not be allowed inside school premises; there should be a separate room provided for mid-day meals.

Lavatory : Privies and urinals should be provided - one urinal for 60 students and one latrine for 100 students. Arrangements should be separately made for boys and girls.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician with a rash on the palms and soles of his feet as well as fever and headache. His mother reports that a tick bit him while camping the week prior. His Weil-Felix: test result is positive, suggesting Rocky Mountain spotted fever. What agent should be given to treat this condition?
questions.solution: Doxycycline, a tetracycline (30S ribosome inhibitor), is the antibiotic of choice to treat Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a rickettsial disease. Streptomycin can be used to treat plague and brucellosis. Bacitracin is only used topically. Ciprofloxacin can be used to treat anthrax, and erythromycin is the most effective drug for the treatment of Legionnaires disease.

questions.text: The CSF from a 2-week-old infant with meningitis shows rods with tumbling motility. These bacteria are found to be Gram-positive and do not form spores. What is the most likely agent?
questions.solution: Listeria is the correct answer. Both Bacillus and Clostridium can be eliminated because they are spore-formers. Actinomyces is Gram-positive and nonmotile and is not a common causative agent of neonatal meningitis. Listeria has a tumbling motility when grown in broth, in this case CSF.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presented to the infusion center for her first cycle of chemotherapy for stage III breast cancer. She is started on doxorubicin plus cyclophosphamide. The oncologist prescribes ondansetron and dexamethasone to prevent nausea and vomiting. In addition, he writes a prescription for a medication that will prevent delayed nausea and vomiting and augment the effect of the other antinausea medications. What medication was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution: Aprepitant is the first available substance P antagonist used for the prevention of both sudden and delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. It can be used synergistically with serotonin 5-HT3 antagonists, such as ondansetron, and corticosteroids, such as dexamethasone. While the other drugs are used for the management of nausea and vomiting, they do not necessarily augment the effect of ondansetron and dexamethasone. In addition, they are not approved to help with delayed nausea and vomiting.

questions.solution: Giant cell tumor is characterized by the presence of numerous multinucleated osteoclast- type giant cells. They develop within the epiphysis and may extend into the metaphysis. The neoplastic cells are primitive osteoblast precursors that express high levels of RANKL, which in turn promotes the proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their differentiation into mature osteoclasts. The majority are near the knee, involving the distal femur or proximal tibia and may cause arthritis-like symptoms. Most common location of giant cell tumor of bone with a pathologic fracture is the distal femur.

questions.text: What constitutes the axis of Receiver Operator Characteristic (ROC) curve ?
questions.solution:
• In a ROC curve the true positive rate (Sensitivity) is plotted in function of the false positive rate (1-Specificity) for different cut-off points of a parameter.
  • Each point on the ROC curve represents a sensitivity/specificity pair corresponding to a particular decision threshold.
  • The area under the ROC curve (AUC) is a measure of how well a parameter can distinguish between two diagnostic groups (diseased/normal).

questions.text: An 83-year-old who still lives in her own home has developed pneumonia following influenza. The Gram stain of her sputa is shown. What is the most likely agent?
questions.solution: The most common cause of pneumonia in people over 65 years of age has generally been S. pneumoniae. Although the other agents also cause pneumonia, S. pneumoniae is the only organism that fits the descriptions of Gram-positive cocci in chains. It is also quite common following influenza. If the woman had not been vaccinated for influenza, then she also may not have been vaccinated for pneumococcus.

questions.text: A mother takes her 7-year-old girl to urgent care for a persistent cough that results in vomiting episodes after prolonged coughing spells. Further workup, including a throat culture, is negative. Which of the following medications could be used to manage her current symptoms?
questions.solution: Dextromethorphan is an opioid isomer available in over-the-counter cough remedies. It has no analgesic properties and limited abuse potential at recommended doses. Tramadol is a weak µ- opioid-receptoragonist,. which also blocks serotonin and norepinephrine uptake and is used for neuropathic pain. Diphenoxylate is an opioid that, combined with atropine, is taken orally to treat diarrhea. Loperamide is an opioid that does not cross the bloodbrain barrier and is also used for the treatment of diarrhea. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used to reverse opioid overdose.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy visits his dentist for a routine checkup and is told his wisdom teeth are severely impacted and should be removed. He is referred to an oral surgeon who uses an anesthetic with good analgesic and sedative properties but does not cause skeletal muscle relaxation. Which of the following anesthetic agents was used?
questions.solution: Nitrous oxide is an anesthetic gas that has good analgesic and sedative properties without the skeletal muscle-relaxing effects. It can be used along with other inhaled agents decreasing their concentrations and thus their side effects. Enflurane produces anesthesia, hypnosis, and muscle relaxation, as do the others, and is very pungent.Halothane has a pleasant odor and produces a smooth and relatively rapid induction but decreases cardiac output and can result in an unpredictable hepatotoxicity. Isoflurane is associated with more rapid induction and recovery than halothane and may have some benefits in patients with ischemic heart disease

questions.text: A 28 year old man with fever, chills, night sweats. He presented with a non-tender mass in the supraclavicular region. Hodgkin lymphoma arises in a single node or chain of nodes and spreads first to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. Morphologically, the distinctive feature of Hodgkin lymphoma is the presence of neoplastic giant cells called Reed-Sternberg cells.

Hodgkin lymphoma most commonly presents as painless lymphadenopathy, fever, night sweats and weight loss.

questions.text: Bed-occupancy rate is an example of:
questions.solution:
Utilization of services - or actual coverage - is expressed as the proportion of people in need of a service who actually receive it in a given period, usually a year. Example:

  1. proportion of infants who are “fully immunized” against the 6 EPI diseases.
  2. proportion of pregnant women who receive antenatal care, or have their deliveries supervised by a trained birth attendant.
  3. percentage of the population using the various methods of family planning.
  4. bed-occupancy rate (i.e., average daily in-patient census/average number of beds).
  5. average length of stay (i.e., days of care rendered/ discharges), and
  6. bed turnover ratio (i.e., discharges/average beds).

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with breast cancer undergoes a breast-conserving lumpectomy and lymph node biopsy. Following radiation therapy, a chemotherapy regimen is started that includes paclitaxel. Which adverse effect may the patient experience due to this drug?
questions.solution: Common adverse effects of paclitaxel include myelosuppression and peripheral neuropathy. The neuropathy usually manifests as numbness and tingling in the distal extremities. Hematuria, or blood in the urine, can indicate hemorrhagic cystitis, a complication of cyclophosphamide use. Arrhythmias may occur with acute cardiac toxicity due to anthracycline therapy. Hot flashes are a common complaint in patients tamoxifen. Shortness of breath can result from pulmonary fibrosis secondary to busulfan or bleomycin use.

questions.text: What is the denominator for the calculation of the negative predictive value of the screening test?
questions.solution:
Option A: True negative + False negative

  • A negative predictive value defines as the probability of having a disease negative if the test is negative.
  • The formula for Negative Predictive value is as follows:
    • Negative predictive value = True negative / True negative + false negative.
    • Therefore, choice A is correct.

Option B: False positive + True negative

  • Specificity defines as the ability of the test to identify correctly those who do not have the disease.
  • For which the denominator is False positive and true negative.

Option C: True positive + False positive

  • The positive predictive value defines as what is the probability of having a disease if the test is positive.
  • For which the denominator is true positive and false positive.

Option D: True positive + True negative

  • Above mentioned choice is not a denominator for the negative predictive value.

questions.text: Which Committee recommended separate staff for the family planning programme?
questions.solution: Mukerji committee A committee known as"Mukerji Committee, 1965" under the Chairmanship of Shri Mukerji, the Secretary of Health to the Government of India, was appointed to review the strategy for the family planning programme. The . Committee recommended separate staff for the family planning programme. The family planning assistants were to undertake family planning duties only. The basic health workers were to be utilized for purposes other than family planning. The Committee also recommended to delink the malaria activities from family planning so that the latter would receive undivided attention of its staff.

questions.text: A uretric transection injury is detected during a difficult abdominal hysterectomy at the level of uterine arteries, while attempting to secure bleeding. Which of the following measures should be done next?

choices.text: Placement of a ureteral stent without anastomosis

questions.solution:
Implanting a severed ureter into the bladder is the procedure of choice, especially when the ureteral transection is near the bladder, as would be expected in this case.

Following an injury to the ureter during surgery, a drain should be placed extraperitoneally, not intraperitoneally. If a polyethylene catheter is inserted, it should be placed above the site of injury so that urine is drained before arrival at the site of injury.

Ureteroureteral anastomosis should be done only if reimplantation into the bladder is not feasible.

questions.text: Excision of ranula is associated with injury to:-
questions.solution:
Excision of ranula is associated with injury to submandibular duct.

"The treatment of ranula constitute a problem, owing to technical difficulty of complete excision without damage to adjacent structures such as submandibular duct."-Clinical Surgery by Rob’s and Smith vol-9/56

RANULA

  • Acystic swelling in the floor of mouththat resembles afrog bellyQ.
  • Term ranula should only be applied to a mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual glandQ

ETIOLOGY

  • Commonly the lesion is induced by local trauma and duct rupture, followed by mucin spillage into the surrounding soft tissues (mucous extravasation phenomenon)Q
  • Uncommonly, it is due to obstruction, probably caused by mucous plug or a sialolith

HISTOPATHOLOGY

  • Mucin accumulation surrounded by granulation and fibrous tissue (mucous extravasation phenomenon)Q
  • A cyst cavity, filled with mucin and lining by the ductal epithelium(mucous retention cyst)Q
  • Chronic inflammation of the cyst wall is present. Infiltration by numerous neutrophils, histiocytes, and plasma cells are commonQ.

CLINICAL FEATURES

  • Exclusively present on the floor of mouthQ; Usually unilateral, lateral to midlineQ
  • Smooth, dome shape, fluctuating and painless swellingQ
  • The color is usually bluish, but deep lesions may have a normal color.
  • The size varies from a few to several centimeters in diameter. Very large lesions which may occupy the floor of mouth can also occur.

DIAGNOSIS:Diagnosis is usually made clinicallyQ.

TREATMENT

  • Surgical removal or marsupializationQ.
  • MC structure injured during ranula surgery: Submandibular ductQ

In addition to the stomach, the subhepatic space may be involved with infec-tion secondary to injury or diseases of the the gallbladder, the first part of the duodenum, the anterior portions of the pancreas, or the liver. questions.text: This type of pattern is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
SINUSOIDAL PATTERN – A regular, smooth, undulating signal, resembling a sine wave, with an amplitude of 5-15 bpm, and a frequency of 3-5 cycles per minute. This pattern lasts more than 30 minutes, and coincides with absent accelerations.

The pathophysiological basis of the sinusoidal pattern is incompletely understood, but it occurs in association with severe fetal anemia, like in Anti-D allo-immunisation

Fetal-maternal hemorrhage

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome

Ruptured vasa praevia.

It has also been described in cases of:

Acute fetal hypoxia,

Infection,

Cardiac malformations Hydrocephalus

Gastroschisis

PSEUDO-SINUSOIDAL PATTERN – A pattern resembling the sinusoidal pattern, but with a more jagged “saw-tooth” appearance, rather than the smooth sine-wave form

Its duration seldom exceeds 30 minutes and it is characterised by normal patterns before and after.

This pattern has been described after analgesic administration to the mother, and during periods of fetal sucking and other mouth movements

questions.text: A 22 day old baby girl comes to the OPD with decreased responses to mothers actions. questions.solution:
In congenital rubella syndrome (CRS), fetal infection occurs transplacentally during the maternal viremic phase.The risk of transmission to the fetus depends on the time of maternal infection; when infection with rubella occurs before 10 weeks of gestation, it may cause multiple fetal defects in up to 90% of cases. questions.text: A 30 year old man with an ovoid swelling over his right eyelid came to the clinic. On examination, the swelling appeared to be mobile, well- defined and soft on palpation. He reported that the lesion had begun to develop 5 years ago, without any significant medical history. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: An orbital dermoid cyst is a choristoma (a mass of histologically normal tissue in an abnormal location) derived from displacement of ectoderm to a subcutaneous location along embryonic lines of closure. Dermoids are lined by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium (like skin), have a fibrous wall and contain dermal appendages such as sweat glands, sebaceous glands and hair follicles; epidermoid cysts do not contain adnexal structures. Dermoids may be ‘superficial’ or ‘deep’, located anterior or posterior to the orbital septum respectively. Epibulbar dermoids and dermolipomas are related lesions.

questions.text: All can be used to lower mother to child HIV spread except

choices.text: Omitting ergometrine inj. For PPH control after placenta delivery
Syp. nevirapine to the newborn if breast feeding is done

questions.solution:
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) may be transmitted from an infected mother to her child during pregnancy, delivery or breastfeeding.

Without any intervention, transmission rates may range from 15-45%.

Additional 10-15% more chances if the baby is breastfed

( Breastfeeding is contraIndicated, but is given under Nevirapine prophylaxis in developing countries)

However, this can be reduced to < 5% with effective drug therapy.

that all pregnant and breastfeeding women should receive ART irrespective of clinical stage of disease or CD4 count.

Three-drug ART has reduced maternal-fetal HIV transmission rate to less than 2%. TDF ( Tenofovir Disoproxil Fumarate) + 3TC ( Lamivudine) (or FTC / emtricitabine) + EFV (Efavirenz) However, the safest and most efficacious combination is not yet clear

There is growing evidence of the safety of TDF and FTC + TDF during pregnancy and breastfeeding when used for treating maternal HIV or HBV.

Cesarean section is not known to reduce the incidence of mother to child transmission anymore than normal delivery now.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female complaints of headache, palpitations, and increased sweating. Her blood pressure was 180/100 mm Hg. On examination, urinary catecholamines and their metabolites were found to be elevated. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: They may arise from sympathetic ganglions

questions.solution:
Option A: 90% are malignant

  • The given condition is pheochromocytoma. They arise from sympathetic ganglia and secrete catecholamines
  • According to the rule of 10, pheochromocytomas are:
    • 10%- bilateral
    • 10% - malignant
    • 10% - occur in pediatric patients
    • 10% - extra-adrenal
    • 10% - familial
  • Extra adrenal tumors, also called functional paragangliomas, may be found at sites of sympathetic ganglia in the
    • Organ of Zuckerkandl
    • Neck
    • Mediastinum
    • Abdomen and pelvis

 

                     

Option B: 10% occur in the abdomen

  • Most pheochromocytomas arise in the adrenal medulla. Almost 10% of pheochromocytomas are extra-adrenal.

Option C: Pheochromocytoma releases catecholamines

  • Pheochromocytomas are catecholamine-secreting tumors. They release epinephrine and norepinephrine.

Option D: They arise from sympathetic ganglions

  • Pheochromocytomas originate from the sympathetic ganglia.

questions.text: Fetal condition associated with increased maternal age is:
questions.solution:
Women at high-risk of giving birth to a child with Down syndrome are:

  • Those over 35 years of age
  • Those who have had a previous child with the syndrome

Screening:

With the advent of detection of ‘Cell free fetal DNA’ in maternal circulation, many invasive tests like amniocentesis can be delayed or even avoided.

Using massively parallel sequencing or chromosome selective sequencing to isolate cell-free fetal DNA from maternal plasma, fetal Down syndrome and other autosomal trisomies may be detected as early as 10 weeks’ gestation

detection rates for trisomies 21, 18, and 13 of approximately 98 percent at a FALSE-positive rate of 0.5 percent or less

If an abnormal result is identified, genetic counselling should be performed, and invasive prenatal diagnostic testing should be offered to confirm the results.

The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists currently recommends that the test may be offered to the following groups:

• Women 35 years or older at delivery

• Those with sonographic findings indicating increased risk for fetal aneuploidy

• Those with a prior pregnancy complicated by trisomy 21, 18, or 13

• Patient or partner carries a balanced robertsonian translocation indicating increased risk for fetal trisomy 21 or 13

• Those with an abnormal first-, second-, or combined first and second-trimester screening test result for aneuploidy.

questions.text: Psoriasis displayes:
questions.solution: In psoriasis, the basal layer divides too fast. Hence, the basal cells reach the subcuteanous faster and do not have time to shed the nucleus (normally, it takes 4 weeks to shed the nucleus). Hence, as nuclei are retained in psoriasis, nucleated stratum corneum is seen on histopathology. This is called parakeratosis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female was scheduled for herniorrhaphy. During the surgery, the surgeon observed that the shape of the hernia was in a “W” shape, as shown in the image below. What is the name of the hernia?
questions.solution:
Option D: Maydl's hernia 

  • The picture shown above is that of a Maydl hernia.
  • Maydl's hernia is an uncommon kind that can be fatal if left untreated.
  • The hernial sac has two loops of the bowel, one of which is intra-abdominal. The hernial sac contains a loop of the bowel in the shape of a 'W', and the centre section of the 'W' loop may become strangulated, either alone or in conjunction with the bowel in the hernial sac.
  • It is more common in men and primarily on the right side. Patients with massive incarcerated hernias and signs of intra-abdominal strangulation or peritonitis should be suspected of having Maydl's hernia. Postural or manual hernia reduction is not recommended since it may miss non-viable intestines.

Option A: Richter’s hernia

  • A Richter's hernia arises when the intestine's antimesenteric wall protrudes through a hole in the abdominal wall.
  • It is unique from other forms of abdominal hernias in that only one intestinal wall protrudes through the opening, resulting in an incompletely contained intestine lumen in the defect, with the remainder remaining in the peritoneal cavity.
  • Perforation and peritonitis may occur if such a herniation develops necrotic and is minimised during hernia surgery.
  • Without intestinal blockage, a Richter's hernia can cause strangulation and necrosis.
  • Resection and anastomosis are used to treat the condition. Delays in surgical intervention increase mortality.

Option B: Littre's hernia

  • The protrusion of a Meckel diverticulum through a possible abdominal orifice is referred to as a Littre hernia.
  • Littre hernias are most commonly seen in the inguinal (50%), umbilical (20%), and femoral (20%) regions.
  • The ileal loop to which it is linked may accompany the Meckel diverticulum in the sac; on rare occasions, it may endure imprisonment or strangulation, necrosis, and perforation.
  • It is especially common in children with umbilical hernias, and the diverticulum is more likely to cling to the sac.

  • Littre hernia repair comprises diverticulum excision and herniorrhaphy; in perforated instances, care must be given not to contaminate the hernia area.

Option C: Pantaloon hernia

  • A pantaloon hernia, also known as a "Saddlebag" hernia, is defined as any combination of two contiguous femoral or inguinal hernia sacs on the same side (direct or indirect inguinal hernias).
  • Femoral with direct hernias, femoral with indirect hernias, and indirect with direct hernias are all examples.
  • The Romberg hernia is a pantaloon hernia that exclusively consists of ipsilateral indirect and direct hernias. Hernial sacs can be found on both sides of the inferior epigastric vessels, separated by the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, which has been pushed down by the direct hernia.

Prior to the block she had developed bilateral carpo-pedal spasm which resolved spontaneously soon after the subarachnoid block was established. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Without analgesia, a labouring woman can demonstrate a very high hyperventilatory response, with marked hypocapnia (PaCO2 as low as 2kPa). This can lead to an acute reduction in ionised calcium leading to these symptoms.

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-year-old boy to the medicine outpatient department with a complaint of fever for 5 days. On examination, the child has red eyes. The patient also had dry as well as cracked lips. The child was also having rashes on his hands and feet. The doctor also noticed edema on his soles and palms and had unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. The patient also had a red tongue. The doctor suggested radiological imaging of coronary arteries to confirm the suspected vasculitis. Closely observe the image and analyze the symptoms mentioned above. Choose the correct statement regarding the disease

choices.text: IV immunoglobulin is used in treatment

questions.solution:
Option C: IV immunoglobulin is used in the treatment

  • The image show child having a strawberry tongue

Kawasaki disease:

  • Also known as "mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome."
  • Most common vasculitis in children aged less than 4 years.
  • It is a Necrotizing Vasculitis involving Medium-sized vessels, most commonly the Coronary arteries.
  • Diagnostic Criteria for Kawasaki Disease:
  • Fever lasting for at least 5 days + at least 4 out of 5 characteristic symptoms should be present:
    • Conjunctivitis (bilateral)
    • Rash, primary truncal
    • Asymmetric cervical lymphadenitis
    • Crusting of lips, fissuring of mouth and oropharyngeal erythema
    • Oedema & erythema of palms & soles
    • Adenopathy
    • Mucosal involvement: Strawberry tongue
  • Management:
    • High dose Aspirin and IV immunoglobin.
    • Steroids are contraindicated (danger of vessel rupture).
    • Add Warfarin if there is a high risk of thrombosis (very high platelet count).

Option A:  Aspirin is contraindicated in this disease

  • Aspirin is an NSAID. Also known as acetylsalicylic acid.
  • It is used to treat inflammation, minor aches/pain and fever.
  • Aspirin is given with IV Immunoglobin in Kawasaki to prevent abnormalities in the coronary artery.
  • It prevents the development of Myocardial infarction in a patient with Kawasaki disease.
  • Aspirin is contraindicated in bleeding disorders and patients under 16 years except in Kawasaki disease.

Option B:  Bilateral purulent conjunctivitis is present

  • Purulent conjunctivitis is a violently severe conjunctival infection.
  • The patient is presented with profuse pus (white or coloured), eye pain/itch/puffiness and a clear propensity for corneal involvement.
  • Purulent conjunctivitis is most commonly caused by N. gonorrhoea and Neisseria meningitidis
  • The patients have bulbar congestion in Kawasaki Disease.
  • There is an Absence of any discharge.

Option D: Lymphadenopathy is rare

  • Lymphadenopathy means swelling of lymph nodes.
  • Swelling of lymph nodes occurs due to
    • Infections,
    • Autoimmune diseases,
    • Malignancies
    • Drug reactions.
  • The patients develop  Unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy with fever in the initial part of Kawasaki Disease.
  • Kawasaki illness also causes swelling in the glands (lymph nodes) and mucous membranes within the mouth, nose, eyes, and throat.
  • Formerly referred to as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with her husband due to vomiting, constipation and abdominal distention. A Plain X-ray of the abdomen reveals multiple air-fluid levels. Vaginal examination shows a loop of extra tissue resembling the intestine protruding from the cervix. Which of the following history must be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: History of dilatation and curettage

Figure: The uterine perforation after dilation and curettage

  • This patient has presented with symptoms of intestinal obstruction with the intestine protruding through the cervix, suggestive of uterine perforation. In the non-pregnant state, perforation of the uterus usually occurs during dilatation and curettage.
  • Prolapsed intestines could be due to evacuation pull by an ovum forceps through the perforation or by a suction curette.
  • Dilatation and curettage procedures are primary tools for the diagnostic evaluation and treatment of abnormal uterine bleeding.
  • Perforation of the uterus is common during a state of pregnancy or malignancy (Soft Uterus) and more common in medical termination of pregnancy for advanced gestation.
  • The atrophic uterus of post-menopausal women may also be perforated easily during D&C.
  • IUCD insertion also causes perforation, especially if done in a hurry.
  • In case of a perforation, if the uterus is empty, simple observation will suffice. However, in complicated cases hysterectomy is done. Often abdominal viscera prolapse through the perforation, and hence a laparotomy is done to repair the defect of the bowel or bladder.

Option A: History of IUCD insertion

  • IUCD insertion can also cause uterine perforation, but it is unlikely to damage to this extent.

Option C: History of laparoscopic surgery

  • Multiple types of complications can occur during laparoscopic surgeries. Perforation of viscus is one of them.
  • But laparoscopic surgery would not cause an unnoticed perforation of the uterus or any other organ as the procedure is done under vision.

Option D: History suggestive of carcinoma endometrium

  • Endometrial cancer can invade through the myometrium but not cause such an acute adverse injury.

Tardive dyskinesia is a side effect of antipsychotic medications. These drugs are used to treat schizophrenia and other mental health disorders. TD causes stiff, jerky movements of your face and body that you can't control. You might blink your eyes, stick out your tongue, or wave your arms without meaning to do so.

questions.text: Which of the following surgical procedures has the highest incidence of postoperative respiratory complications?
questions.solution:
The risk of overall postoperative respiratory complications is about 25% with open abdominal aortic surgery. The incidence of postoperative pneumonia is higher with abdominal aortic surgery compared to thoracic surgery (odds ratio 4.3 versus 3.9).

Endovascular repair is associated with a much lower risk of postoperative pneumonia as compared to an open procedure.

questions.text: In the following picture, the placental separation is called:
questions.solution: The retroplacental hematoma either follows the placenta or is found within the inverted sac formed by the membranes. In this process, known as the Schultze mechanism of placental expulsion, blood from the placental site pours into the membrane sac and does not escape externally until after extrusion of the placenta. In the other form of placental extrusion, known as the Duncan mechanism, the placenta separates first at the periphery and blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall and escapes from the vagina. In this circumstance, the placenta descends sideways, and its maternal surface appears first.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause Bulls-eye maculopathy as a serious side effect?
questions.solution: Bulls-eye maculopathy is atrophy of retinal pigmented epithelium in the region of the macula. It is seen as alternate hyperpigmented and hypopigmented zones which resemble Bulls-eye.

questions.text: Determinants of cerebral blood flow include:
questions.solution: Determinants of cerebral blood flow include arterial CO 2 and O 2 tensions, systemic arterial pressure, and temperature. Other factors that may affect cerebral blood flow and intracranial pressure are head position, jugular venous obstruction, and positive end-expiratory pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause Polyuria?
questions.solution:
• Rhabdomyolysis leads to myoglobinuria which leads to blockage of tubules and thereby reduction of urine output.
  • Interstitial nephritis is characterized by tubular damage leading to polyuria.
  • Hypokalemic nephropathy in choice B and ADH insufficiency (diabetes insipidus) in choice C leads to Polyuria.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a generalised tonic-clonic seizure. His wife reports that he has been having episodic headaches, nausea, and progressive weakness for the past several weeks. The headaches are particularly worse at night and occasionally awaken him. Other medical conditions include well-controlled hypertension and osteoarthritis. On physical examination, the patient is postictal but follows simple commands. CT scan of the head shows a space-occupying lesion in the left cerebral hemisphere and dilated ventricles. Which of the following are considered signs of raised ICP?


	Blurring of disc margins
	Positive Kernig Sign
	Ipsilateral pupil dilatation
	Ipsilateral hemiplegia
questions.solution:
Option C: 1, 3, 4 only

  • The pressure in the cranial vault is measured in millimetres of mercury (mm Hg) and is normally less than 20 mmHg.
  • The cranium is a rigid structure that contains 3 main components: brain, cerebrospinal fluid, and blood. Any increase in the volume of its contents will increase the pressure within the cranial vault.
  • An increase in the volume of one component will result in a decrease in the volume of one or two of the other components.
  • The clinical implication of the change in the volume of the component is a decrease in cerebral blood flow or herniation of the brain.
  • Blurring of disc margins (papilledema), ipsilateral pupil dilation, and ipsilateral hemiplegia are signs of raised intracranial pressure.
  • Blurring of disc margins is an early finding in papilledema
  • Positive Kernig sign is a feature of meningeal irritation and not raised ICP.
  • Ipsilateral hemiplegia occurs due to the Kernohan Woltman sign seen in uncal herniation.
  • Ipsilateral pupil dilatation: The pupil of the same side of the CNS lesion dilates and shows a sluggish reaction to light. It is seen in uncal herniation and is called Hutchinson’s pupil.

Option A: 1, 2, 3 only

  • Positive Kernig sign is a feature of meningeal irritation and not raised ICP.
  • Therefore, it is an incorrect option.

Option B: 2, 3, 4 only

  • Positive Kernig sign is a feature of meningeal irritation and not raised ICP.
  • However, blurring the disc is a common feature in raised ICP.

Option D: 2 & 4 only

  • Positive Kernig sign is a feature of meningeal irritation and not raised ICP.
  • However, blurring the disc is a common feature in raised ICP.
  • Ipsilateral pupil dilation can occur in case of the same-sided CNS lesion; the pupil dilates and shows a sluggish reaction to light. It is seen in uncal herniation and is called Hutchinson’s pupil.

questions.text: Imprinting of the fetus in the diabetic mother suggests that exposure to hyperglycemia leads to hyperinsulinemia, causing an increase in which fetal cell type and leading to obesity and insulin resistance in childhood?
questions.solution: In utero exposure to maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperinsulinemia, causing an increase in fetal fat cells, which leads to obesity and insulin resistance in childhood . This in turn leads to impaired glucose tolerance and diabetes in adulthood.

questions.text: A patient is being weaned from mechanical ventilation. Weaning parameters are obtained prior to deciding on extubation. Successful weaning from a ventilator is suggested by the presence of which of the following?

choices.text: An alveolar arterial gradient of more than 350 mm Hg
A tidal volume of over 5 mL/kg

questions.solution:
Successful weaning from the ventilator is suggested by the presence of

  1. PaO2 of 70 mm Hg or more with an FiO2 of 0.35 or less
  2. An alveolar arterial gradient of <350 mm Hg
  3. A PaO2-to-FiO2 ratio of >200
  4. A PaCO2 of over 30 mm Hg and <55 mm Hg
  5. A VC of more than 10–15 mL/kg
  6. A maximum negative inspiratory force of more than -25 cm H2O
  7. A minute ventilation of <10 L/min
  8. A tidal volume of over 5 mL/kg
  9. A respiratory rate of <30 breaths/min

questions.text: A 47-year-old female with a history of Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome who has been non-compliant with warfarin presents with deep vein thrombosis and dyspnea. She is hypotensive and tachypneic. CT of the chest shows a saddle embolus. She does not respond to heparin and fluids. The echocardiogram shows RV hypokinesis. Which of the following is appropriate management?

choices.text: Continue administration of fluids and heparin

questions.solution:
Option B: Recombinant tissue plasminogen activator

  • The clinical scenario mentioned here points toward a Massive pulmonary embolism.

  • This female is in a hypercoagulable state, and one has to do thrombolysis with a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA)

  • Massive pulmonary embolism is described as obstruction of the pulmonary arterial tree that surpasses fifty percent of the cross-sectional area, resulting in acute and severe cardiopulmonary failure from right ventricular overload.

  • This condition can be fatal.

  • Anticoagulation and thrombolysis are the two primary therapy modalities that are utilized when dealing with pulmonary embolism. An embolectomy using surgical means has also been described for use in extreme instances.

  • On the basis of clinical criteria and a high index of suspicion for pulmonary embolism, immediate pulmonary embolectomy needs to be performed when there is a massive pulmonary embolism that is accompanied by cardiopulmonary collapse.

  • This prevents time-consuming imaging examinations from being performed.

  • Compared to anticoagulation therapy alone, thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator plus anticoagulation can lead to greater improvement of right ventricular dysfunction and reduction in clot burden in patients who have massive pulmonary embolism and a low risk of bleeding.

Option A: Urgent referral for surgical embolectomy

  • Referral for surgical embolectomy is only to be done in case there is a contraindication for thrombolysis.

Option C: Continue administration of fluids and heparin

  • Fluids will not be given because in question already mentioned that RV Hypokinesia & fluid will further deteriorate the condition.

Option D: Add lepirudin

  • Lepirudin is used in heparin-induced Thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old suffering from chronic alcoholism is admitted to the hospital. He has muscle tremors and hyperactive tendon reflexes. Serum magnesium is 1.8 mEq/L (normal 1.5–2.5 mEq/L). Concerning magnesium, which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Excess may cause a positive Chvostek’s sign (carpopedal spasm)
Deficiency is treated with parenteral bicarbonate
Symptoms are due to deficiency of magnesium

questions.solution: Symptoms are due to magnesium deficiency.Magnesium is mainly intracellular. Magnesium deficiency occurs in the presence of starvation, malabsorption syndrome, acute pancreatitis, and chronic alcoholism. Symptoms are characterized by neuromuscular and CNS hyperactivity, such as muscle tremors, hyperactive tendon reflexes, and tetany with a positive Chvostek sign. The syndrome of magnesium deficiency can exist in the presence of normal serum magnesium levels. Magnesium deficiency is treated with parenteral magnesium sulfate or magnesium chloride.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding myelofibrosis except:
questions.solution:
Myelofibrosis

  1. Striking splenomegaly
  2. Dacryocytes (teardrop-shaped red blood cells) are common.Nucleated red blood cells and aniso-poikilocytosis are also frequently seen. Myelocytes and Promyelocytes are present in small proportions in most patients; blasts may also be seen. Platelets may be large or unusually shaped. In rare cases, the platelet count may be elevated
  3. Tear drop (poikilocytosis) on peripheral smear
  4. Leukoerythroblastic blood picture
  5. Giant abnormal platelets.

questions.text: A 4 year old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother due toabnormal behaviour. She reports that he does not respond to affection, does not smile, doesn’t want to play with other kids, spends most of his time alone with his toys. She also says that he is very particular about his toys, he always arranges them in a particular fashion and gets very agitated upon change. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Autism spectrum disorder is a neurodevelopmental disorder that is characterized by social communication and interaction deficit and restricted repetitive patterns of behavior, interest and activities.

Social communication and social interaction deficit in many contexts such as

  • lack of social-emotional reciprocity
  • lack of nonverbal communicative behaviors
  • impairment in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships Restricted and repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities such as
  • motor movements that are stereotyped or repetitive (e.g., flipping objects)
  • inflexibility to change
  • restricted and fixated interests
  • hyper- or hyporeactivity or unusual interest in a sensory stimulus (e.g., fascination with lights)

These symptoms must be present in the patient's early developmental period in the absence of an organic etiology (e.g., hearing dysfunction)

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with complaints of bilateral flank pain with progressive enlargement of the abdomen. He also gives a history of the sudden death of one of his adult family members. On ultrasonography, he is found to have multiple cysts on both kidneys. Which of the following would be the most common extra-renal involvement in this renal condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hepatic cysts

  • The history, clinical signs and radiological findings lead us to the diagnosis of ADPKD in this patient.
  • The progressive enlargement of the abdomen along with bilateral flank pain in this middle-aged man gives a clue regarding the enlargement of the kidneys because of multiple cyst formations.
  • A history of the sudden death of one of the family members is most likely because of subarachnoid haemorrhage secondary to the rupture of the berry aneurysms associated with this disease, i.e. ADPKD, the presence of which in a family member depicts Autosomal dominance in the inheritance of the disease.
  • The extra-renal manifestations of ADPKD include Mitral valve prolapse, berry aneurysms, hepatic cysts, and colonic diverticulosis.
  • The overall prevalence of hepatic cysts is about 83% in patients with ADPKD.So most common extrarenal manifestation of ADPKD

Option A: Mitral valve prolapse

  • Mitral valve prolapse may be found in up to one-third of patients with ADPKD but is not as common as the hepatic cyst.

Option C: Splenic cysts

  • Splenic cysts are not usually associated with ADPKD.

Option D: Colonic diverticulosis

  • Colonic diverticulosis is much less common in association with ADPKD as compared to Hepatic cysts or Mitral valve prolapse.

questions.text: "Hegar's sign" can be elicited in:
questions.solution:
Hegar's sign:

  • On a per vaginal examination, the abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to oppose below the body of uterus.
  • Seen around 6th week

questions.text: Which of the following reflexes persists throughout life?
questions.solution:
Parachute reflex - Holding the infant in an upright position, followed by sudden lowering towards the examination table elicits extension of the infant's arms.This reflex appears at 6–9 months of age and persists throughout life.

Moro reflex- Holding an infant in the supine position while supporting the head, then allowing the head to suddenly fall back elicits abduction and extension of the infant's arms and elbows, followed by their flexion.It resolutes in 3-6months

Plantar reflex- Stroking the sole of the foot from heel to toe elicits dorsiflexion of the foot with concomitant extension of the big toe and fanning of the other toes. It resolutes by 12 months

Galant reflex- Holding the infant in the prone position and stroking it on one side of the paravertebral region elicits flexion of the lower back and hip towards the stimulus. It resolutes by 2-6months

questions.text: Fluorescent imaging:

choices.text: has lower stability compared to radioisotopes
detects photon of a wavelength longer than X-ray

questions.solution: Fluorescent antibodies such as PCR primers can be stored for several months; however, radioisotope-labelled antibodies, for example, phosphorus-32-labelled nucleotides, decay in about a week.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with an ulcerated lesion on his right lateral leg for several weeks (given in the image below). He occasionally has cramping in his calf when walking. His dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are not palpable. The ulcer has a punched out edge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Here , an old age man with history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia is more prone to atherosclerosis and hence peripheral vascular disease. He also has occasional cramping during walking which signifies intermittent claudication which is pathognomic and also there is absent of peripheral pulsation which indicates a case of peripheral vascular disease which has lead to punched out ulcer formation due to ischemia

Ischemic/Arterial ulcers

These wounds occur due to a lack of blood supply and are typically extremely painful in patients with pure ischemic ulcers. They usually are associated with other symptoms of peripheral vascular disease, such as history of intermittent claudication, rest pain and colour or trophic changes. These wounds commonly are present at the most distal portions of the extremities such as the interdigital clefts, although more proximal locations are also encountered. On examination, there may be diminished or absent pulses with decreased ankle brachial index and poor formation of granulation tissue. Other signs of peripheral ischemia such as dryness of skin, hair loss, scaling and pallor can be present. The wound itself is shallow with smooth margins, punched out edge and a pale base and surrounding skin may be present

Venous stasis ulcers

Venous ulcers commonly occur in the Gaiter’s area(area between medial malleolua and tendoachilles). They have sloping edges and floor is filled with healthy granulation tissue. They are due to venous stasis and increased venous pressure. On the microvascular level, there is alteration and distension of dermal capillaries with leakage of fibrinogen which polymerises and leads to perivascular cuffing that can impede oxygen exchange contributing to ulceration(fibrin cuff theory). Another hypothesis is that neutrophils adhere to the capillary endothelium and cause plugging with diminished dermal blood flow leading to ulceration(white cell trapping theory). There occurs extravasation of haemoglobin which breaks down causing pruritus and skin damage.The resulting brownish pigmentation of skin and loss of subcutaneous fat produces lipodermatosclerosis.The cornerstone of treatment of venous ulcer is compression therapy

Diabetic ulcer

The major contributors to the formation of diabetic ulcers include sensory and motor neuropathy, foot deformity and ischemia. The treatment involve local wound management and diabetic control

Decubitus or pressure ulcer

A pressure ulcer is a localised area of tissue necrosis that develops when soft tissue is compressed between a bony prominence and external surface. Pressure ulcer formation is accelerated in the presence of friction, shear force and moisture. The four stages of pressure ulcer formation are:

Stage I - no blanching erythema of intact skin

Stage II - partial thickness skin loss involving epidermis or dermis or both

Stage III - full thickness skin loss but not through the fascia

Stage IV - full thickness skin loss with extensive involvement of muscle and bone

questions.text:
A 76-year-old male patient presented with complaints of painful nodules on the back and upper limbs for several years. She reported the growth of some nodules and an increase in number over time. The patient is obese and has a BMI of 37. On physical examination, skin-coloured subcutaneous nodules all over the upper limbs and on the back were found, as shown in the image below: 



Surgical removal of the painful nodules and anatomopathological examination was performed, which confirmed the proliferation of well-differentiated and uniform adipocytes sitting on a fibrovascular network. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Dercum's disease

  • This patient is most likely suffering from Dercum's disease. Dercum's disease is also referred to as adiposis dolorosa.
  • It is a rare condition characterised by multiple painful lipomas.
  • These lipomas mainly occur on the trunk, upper arms & upper legs, as shown in the image below:

  • Mostly occur between 35-50 years and is more common in women.
  • The clinical features include severe pain.
  • The pain may be caused by lipomas pressing on nearby nerves or inflamed connective tissue.
  • Some patients also experience weight gain, depression, lethargy, and confusion.
  • The exact aetiology of Dercum's disease is unknown.
  • The diagnostic work-up includes detailed patient history and clinical examination to identify typical multiple lipomas.
  • The distribution of the lipomas helps distinguish Dercum's disease from other similar disorders. The histopathological examination of the excised tissue can confirm the diagnosis.
  • As far as the treatment is concerned, no specific treatment is available for Dercum's disease. The patient is managed by conservative measures such as the use of analgesics and injections of corticosteroids.
  • Surgical excision of the mass is indicated in case of severe refractory disease.

Option A: Weber Christian panniculitis

  • Weber Christian panniculitis refers to a group of diseases that involve deep fat. These disorders first appear on the skin as reddish, tender nodules.
  • Systemic symptoms such as fever and body aches are also seen.
  • Usually, both sides of the body are affected, and the thighs and lower legs are the most frequent areas. An oozing of yellowish drainage and scarring is also seen. However, these features are not mentioned in the clinical vignette so that we can rule out this option.

Option C: Liposarcoma

  • Liposarcoma is a type of cancer that occurs in fat cells in the body, most often in the limbs or abdomen muscles. However, this patient's clinical picture suggests Dercum's disease.

Option D: Erythema nodosum

  • Erythema nodosum is a type of skin inflammation located in a part of the fatty layer of the skin.
  • It manifests as reddish, painful, tender lumps most commonly located in the front of the legs below the knees. These features are not present in the vignette so that we can rule out this option.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with a productive cough and dyspnoea. The CT chest of the patient is given below. Which of the following findings is shown in the CT scan?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ground glass pattern

  • Ground-glass opacity (GGO) is a non-specific term defined the as the presence of a hazy increase in lung density on high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) that is not associated with obscuration of the underlying vessels or bronchial walls; if vessels are obscured, the term "consolidation" is preferred.
  • GGO is produced by filling the alveolar gaps (by cells or fluid) or the thickening of the alveolar walls or interstitium.
  • It represents the presence of various lung disorders, such as alveolar collapse, interstitial thickening, or air-space disease.
  • GGO is difficult to identify radiographically, especially in moderate instances, because the differential diagnosis of GGO mostly relies on HRCT.

Option B: Honeycomb pattern

  • The term "honeycomb lung" refers to the appearance of variously sized cysts on a backdrop of heavily scarred lung tissue.
  • Microscopically, there are increased air spaces surrounded by fibrosis and hyperplastic or bronchiolar-type epithelium.
  • These alterations, however, are generic and common in various end-stage interstitial lung illnesses (ILDs).
  • In Usual Interstitial Pneumonitis, a honeycomb pattern is seen on HRCT along with traction bronchiectasis and ground-glass opacities.

Option C: Crazy pavement pattern

  • In pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, the X-ray shows bilateral, diffuse opacities, and the high-resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) shows a crazy-paving pattern.
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) is caused by impaired surfactant clearance that leads to its accumulation in the alveoli.
  • It produces chunky, gelatinous sputum stains with periodic-acid Schiff (PAS) stains.
  • There is little or no lung inflammation, and the underlying lung architecture is preserved.

Option D: Normal Scan

  • It is not a normal CT scan as haziness in the lung fields can be observed instead of air which is usually black on CT.
