questions.text: Name the Presentation ?
questions.solution:
Understanding of this topic is very important before attempting this type of practical questions. Every term is important . Q bank on these modules will further strengthen your concept.

Fetal Presentation
Fetal presentation can be described as the fetal body part, which occupies the lower pole of the uterus and thereby first enters the pelvic passage. Fetal presentation is determined by fetal lie and may be of three types: cephalic (head), podalic (breech), or shoulder .

Cephalic or the head presentation is the most common and occurs in about 97% of fetuses. Breech and shoulder presentations are less common and may pose difficulty for normal vaginal delivery. Thus, these two presentations are also known as malpresentations. As described previously, in cephalic presentation, the fetal head presents first. Depending on the part of fetal head presenting first, cephalic
presentation can be divided as follows:

Vertex or occiput presentation: When the head is completely flexed onto chest, the smallest diameter of the fetal head (suboccipitobregmatic diameter) presents. In these cases, the occiput is the presenting part. Usually the occiput presents anteriorly. In some cases, occiput may be present posteriorly .This type of presentation is known as occipitoposterior position. Though most of the cases with occipitoposterior position undergo normal vaginal delivery, labor is usually prolonged in these cases. In some cases with occipitoposterior presentation, cesarean delivery may be required.

Face presentation: When the fetal head is sharply extended, occiput and the back are in contact with one another. In these cases, face is the foremost part of fetal head inside the birth canal and it presents first.
Brow presentation: When the fetal head is only partially extended, fetal brows are the foremost part of fetal head inside the birth canal and they present first.

Brow presentation is usually transient because with the progress of labor, as further extension of neck takes place, brow presentation almost invariably gets converted into face presentation. If the brow
presentation remains persistent, the labor gets arrested and a cesarean section is almost always required.

Sinciput presentation: When the fetal head is only partially flexed, the anterior fontanel or bregma is the foremost inside the birth canal and it presents. With progress of labor, as the flexion of neck takes place, sinciput presentation invariably gets converted into vertex presentation.

Compound presentation: Compound presentation is a term used when more than one part of the fetus presents .For example, presence of fetal limbs alongside the head in case of a cephalic presentation or one or both arms in case of breech presentation. This can commonly occur in case of preterm infants. Since fetal presentation can undergo a change in the early weeks of gestation, fetal presentation should be reassessed by abdominal palpation at 36 weeks or later, when fetal presentation is unlikely to change by itself and it is likely to influence the plans for the birth. In case of suspected fetal malpresentation, an ultrasound examination must be performed to confirm the presentation.

Presenting Part
This can be defined as the part of fetal presentation which is foremost within the birth canal and is therefore first felt by the clinician’s examining fingers:

• Cephalic: In case of cephalic presentation, the fetal presenting parts are as follows:
– Completely flexed fetal head: Vertex
– Deflexed fetal head: Sinciput
– Partially extended fetal head: Brow
– Completely extended fetal head: Face
• Breech presentation: In case of breech presentation, the fetal presenting part is the sacrum.
• Shoulder presentation: In case of shoulder presentation, fetal presenting part is the back.


Fetal Attitude
Fetal attitude refers to the relationship of fetal parts to each other The most common fetal attitude is that
of flexion in which the fetal head is flexed over the fetal neck;fetal arms are flexed unto chest and the fetal legs are flexed over the abdomen.


Denominator
Denominator can be described as an arbitrary fixed bony point on the fetal presenting part

Fetal presenting part Denominator
Vertex Occiput
Face Mentum
Brow Frontal eminence
Breech Sacrum
Shoulder Acromion

Fetal Position
Fetal position can be defined as the relationship of the denominator to the different quadrants of maternal pelvis(anterior, transverse and posterior). Since the presenting part would be either directed to the left or right side of maternal pelvis, six positions would be possible for each of the fetal presentation. For example, with vertex presentation, the six positions that would be possible are LOA, ROA, LOT, ROT,
LOP and ROP The fetal position gives an idea regarding whether the presenting part is directed towards the front, back, left or right of the birth passage.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to the medical department with pain in the lower back. He also complaints of bloody urine, nausea and vomiting. He tells the doctor about recurrent urination. His vitals are stable. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows a right renal stone. What is the most common renal stone, and how is it treated?

choices.text: Hyper ureic renal stone treated with loop diuretics
Hypercalciuria renal stone treated with thiazide diuretics
Cysteine renal stones treated with spironolactone
Both hypercalciuric and cysteine renal stones

questions.solution:
Option B: Hypercalciuria renal stone treated with thiazide diuretics

  • Patients with renal stones present with lower back pain, fever and bloody urine
  • They are diagnosed through KUB x-ray.
  • The most common renal stones are hypercalciuria
  • These stones are also known as calcium oxalate
  • All types of stone are treated with thiazide diuretics
  • About 80 per cent of this type of stone is present

Option A: Hyper ureic renal stone treated with loop diuretics

  • This is the second most common type of stones
  • Most prevalent in those people with a previous history of diabetes or gout and who are overweight.
  • These are about 5-10 per cent of stones

Option C: Cysteine renal stones treated with spironolactone

  • These are less than 1 per cent
  • A large amount of cysteine that is an amino acid present in the urine, causes these stones

Option D: Both hypercalciuric and cysteine renal stones

  • Only hypercalciuric renal stones are abundant in the renal a stone and are treated with thiazide diuretics.

questions.text: 70 year old male, with long standing history of right-sided nasal obstruction and progressively mounting right nasal cavity growth for the last four years, with occasional epistaxis and nasal itching. There was a friable slightly mobile, erythematous polypoidal mass filling the right nasal cavity on examination. The contralateral nasal cavity was normal. Which of the following is the causative pathogen of the depicted picture?
questions.solution: Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidiumseeberi. In the nose, the disease presents as a leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in colour and attached to nasal septum or lateral wall. Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate. The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch. Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia. In early stages, the patient may complain of nasal discharge which is often blood tinged and nasal stuffiness. Sometimes, frank epistaxis is the only presenting complaint.

questions.text: A patient presented in OPD with symptoms of anaemia, acute abdominal bleeding, tarry stool and vomiting with blood in it. Endoscopy shows strips of watermelon on stomach walls. Which of the following conditions leads to the following endoscopic appearance?
questions.solution:
Option B: Gastric antral vascular ectasia

  • Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) syndrome, also known as watermelon stomach, is a significant cause of acute or chronic gastrointestinal blood loss in the elderly. It is characterized endoscopically by "watermelon stripes.”
  • Although it is associated with heterogeneous medical conditions, including hepatic, renal, and cardiac diseases, its pathogenesis is unknown.
  • The diagnosis of GAVE syndrome in patients with renal or hepatic disease is often problematic because there are more frequent causes of gastrointestinal bleeding in these diseases (vascular malformations, peptic ulcer disease, oesophagal or gastric varices, and colonic and rectal ulcers) that overshadow GAVE syndrome.
  • Gastric antral vascular ectasia:
    • Vascular information→Watermelon stomach

 

Option A: Intestinal lymphangiectasia

  • Biopsy: vacuolated cells because the fat will not be absorbed
  • Primary intestinal lymphangiectasia (PIL) is a rare disorder characterized by dilated intestinal lacteals resulting in lymph leakage into the small bowel lumen and responsible for protein-losing enteropathy leading to lymphopenia, hypoalbuminemia and hypogammaglobulinemia.
  • This disorder results from improperly formed intestinal lymph vessels or blockage of lymph flow from the intestines.
  • Diarrhoea and swelling of the legs are the main symptoms. The diagnosis is based on the results of a biopsy.

 

Option C: Amoebic colitis

  • Biopsy -Flask- shaped ulcer(Bleeding)
  • Amebic colitis is gradual in onset, with symptoms presenting over 1-2 weeks; this pattern distinguishes this condition from bacterial dysentery.
  • Diarrhoea is the most common symptom.
  • Patients with amebic colitis typically present cramping abdominal pain, watery or bloody diarrhoea, and weight loss or anorexia.
  • Amebic colitis results from invasive infection of the colonic mucosa by Entamoeba histolytica (E. histolytica).

 

Option D: Necrotising Enterocolitis

  • Diagnosed by Radiological findings (Pneumatosis intestinalis)
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a severe illness in which tissues in the intestine (gut) become inflamed and start to die.
  • This can lead to a perforation (hole) developing, which allows the contents of the intestine to leak into the abdomen (tummy).

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is brought to the emergency department due to a knife injury. The man was walking home when a thief tried to rob him. While the man attempted to escape, the robber hit his back with a knife. There is a 4cm wide lesion on the back of the patient, just adjacent to the vertebrae. The physician suspects that his injury spread to the spinal cord causing Brown-Sequard syndrome. Which of the following statements is correct regarding Brown-Sequard syndrome?

choices.text: Ipsilateral loss of joint and position sense

questions.solution:
Option C: Ipsilateral loss of joint and position sense.

  • Brown-Sequard syndrome is caused by hemisection of the spinal cord.

  • A loss of motor abilities (paralysis and ataxia) and sensation caused by the lateral hemisection of the spinal cord.

  • It can be caused by penetrating injuries with sharp objects (e.g. knife), infections (tuberculosis), trauma, tumors of the spinal cord, ischemia, or inflammatory diseases (multiple sclerosis).

  • The hemisection of the cord results in a lesion of each of the main neural pathways:

    • Ipsilateral loss of all sensations at the level of the lesion.

    • Ipsilateral lower motor neuron signs (flaccid paralysis) at the level of the lesion.

    • The corticospinal tract lesion produces ipsilateral spastic paralysis (upper motor neuron signs).

    • The lesion to the fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneus (dorsal column) results in ipsilateral loss of vibration and proprioception (position sense). Loss of light touch and 2-point discrimination may occur.

    • The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to pain and temperature sensation being lost from the contralateral side, beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

    • Tactile sensation is not affected much because it is supplied by both crossed and uncrossed pathways.

    • Above the lesion level, hyperesthesia (increased sensation) can occur due to irritation of the dorsal horns.
  • If a lesion occurs above the level of the T1 thoracic vertebra, then the patient can present with ipsilateral Horner syndrome due to damage to the oculosympathetic pathway.

Option A: Contralateral spastic weakness

  • Hemisection of the spinal cord causes ipsilateral (not contralateral) spastic weakness below the lesion level due to damage to the corticospinal tract.

Option B: Ipsilateral cutaneous anesthesia

  • Tactile sensation is not affected much in Brown-Sequard syndrome due to supply by both crossed and uncrossed fibers.

Option D: Contralateral loss of tactile discrimination

  • Ipsilateral (not contralateral) loss of 2-point discrimination (light touch), proprioception, and vibration can occur in Brown-Sequard syndrome.

  • These features are due to dorsal column damage.

One week later he develops a shaking chill in conjunction with a temperature spike to 39.44°C (103°F). His blood pressure is 70/40   mm     Hg with a pulse of 140 beats/min and his respiratory rate is 45 breaths/min. He is transferred to the ICU where he is intubated and a Swan-Ganz catheter is placed.

questions.solution: The case presented is most consistent with septic shock from a postoperative intra-abdominal abscess. In the early phase of septic shock the respiratory profile is characterized by mild hypoxia with a compensatory hyperventilation and respiratory alkalosis. Hemodynamically, a hyperdynamic state is seen with an increase in cardiac output and a decrease in peripheral vascular resistance in the face of relatively normal central pressures. Initial therapy is aimed at resuscitation and stabilization. This includes fluid replacement and vasopressors as well as antibiotic therapy aimed particularly at gram-negative rods and anaerobes for patients with presumed intraabdominal collections, especially after bowel surgery. Laparotomy and drainage of a collection is the definitive therapy but should await stabilization of the patient and confirmation of the presence and location of such a collection.

questions.text: A 40 year old man had multiple hypoesthetic mildly erythematous large plaques with elevated margins on trunk and extremities. His ulnar and lateral popliteal nerves on both sides were enlarged. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Multiple lesions and symmetrical nerve involvement suggests lepromatous kind. However, it can’t be lepromatous leprosy as lepromatous leprosy does not have hypoesthesia. So, it would be one step before lepromatous leprosy, i.e. borderline lepromatous leprosy.

questions.text: A 25 year old man has pigmented macules over the palms, soles and oral mucosa. He also has anemia and abdominal pain. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cushing syndrome Presents with lemon on sticks with hypertension and anemia.
Albright syndrome

McCune – Albright syndrome (MAS) consists of at least 2 of the following 3 features:

  1. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
  2. Café –au- lait skin pigmentation
  3. Autonomous endocrine hyperfunction (eg, gonadotropin – independent)
Peutz jeghers syndrome The lentigines in patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are located primarily around the nose and mouth, on the hands and feet, and within the oral cavity. This is associated with hamartomatous polyps. During the first 3 decades of life, anemia, rectal bleeding, abdominal pain, obstruction, and/or intussusception are common complications in patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.-
Incontinentia pigment The disease has a pediatric presentation Major criteria are (1) typical neonatal vesicular rash with eosinophilia; (2) typical blaschkoid hyperpigmentation on the trunk, fading in adolescence; and (3) linear, atrophic hairless lesions Minor criteria are (1) Dental anomalies (2) Alopecia, (3) wooly hair, and ( 4) abnormal nails.

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with greenish discharge from the eye. He is a frequent contact lens user and complains of regular eye fatigue. On further examination, there is visible ‘bio-film’ formation in his cornea. Which of the following is the causative agent for this type of ulcer?
questions.solution:
‘Bio-film’ formation is the most common cause of corneal ulcer in contact lens users. It is associated with greenish discharge. P. aeruginosa is the most common cause of peripherally located corneal ulcer.

S. pneumoniae - m/c cause of hypopyon bacterial ulcer.

H. influenzae and C. diphtheria are bacteria that can penetrate intact corneal epithelium.

questions.text: Which direction will the left upper lobe collapse on the CT of an elderly female patient who has CXR evidence of a left upper lobe collapse?
questions.solution: Left upper lobe collapse results in volume loss in an anterior and medial direction, as opposed to superior and medial collapse of the right upper lobe collapse.

questions.text: Most common organism responsible for acute bacterial prostatitis:
questions.solution:
The most common cause of bacterial prostatitis is the enterobacteriaceae family of gram – negative bacteria, which originate in the gastrointestinal flora.

The most common organism are strains of Escherichia coli, which are identified in 65% to 80% of infections.”

questions.text: A 11-year-old boy with past medical history of sickle cell disease (homozygote form) comes to the pediatric emergency room with left upper abdominal pain, fever, and episodes of vomit-ing. He is complaining of previous episodes in the past that occurred after heavy meals. A chest x-ray shows the normal heart silhouette in the right chest. A routine abdominal ultrasound shows absence of a gallbladder in the right upper quadrant. The liver parenchyma is seen on the opposite side. Also, the radiologist calls you confused, indicating a thick-walled, fluid-filled cystic structure with echodense particles on the left side, which appears tender on pal-pation. A liver function test is normal except for an alkaline phospatase of 187. WBC is 17.6. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: The patient has constipation and should get an enema to clear out his fecal impaction from the left colon
Preventing a sickle cell crisis, the patient should be placed on additional nasal oxygen, copious hydration, pain medication, and maintaining a hematocrit of >28%.
In addition to preventing a sickle cell crisis, the patient seems to have acute cholecystitis and needs IV antibiotics followed by cholecystectomy
The patient has situs inversus totalis and cholecystectomy is contraindicated

questions.solution: This patient has situs inversus totalis and acute cholecystitis. After ensuring proper treatment of his sickle cell disease, he should receive IV antibiotics and be prepared for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The surgical instrumentarium is to be placed in a mirror image but essentially the same rules and stan-dards apply. The gallstones here probably con-tain bilirubin stones from frequent hemolytic episodes. It is also important to maintain a HCT of >28% and if necessary transfusions with Hb-A blood are carried out preoperatively.

questions.text: Name the Vertex position?
questions.solution: As explained before in details.

questions.text: An 83-year-old male patient had osteoarthritis in the right knee for seven years, with no flexion contracture or high varus or valgus deformity. For the last three days, he started having extreme pain and underwent magnetic resonance imaging, which showed lesions in the medial femoral condyle cartilage in the weight-bearing region. The patient was scheduled for surgery and underwent total knee arthroplasty. Acute arterial occlusion is a rare complication following total knee arthroplasty. Which of the following is the clinical presentation of this complication?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pallor

  • An old man undergoes a major surgery that can dislodge a thrombus resulting in embolus formation causing acute limb ischemia 
  • Acute limb ischemia(ALI) is caused by embolus and less frequently by thrombosis on atherosclerotic plaque.
  • ALI is a sudden decrease in limb perfusion, causing a potential threat to limb viability.
  • The sign and symptoms of classic ALI are described by six P’s:
    • Acute onset of the pain out of proportion
    • Diminished pulse (pulseless)
    • Early skin mottling (pallor)
    • Coolness to touch (perishing cold)
    • Distal paresthesias
    • Paralysis
  • Adequate pain relief should be given as it is very painful. 5000 IU heparin, along with Anti-platelets, should be administered to reduce the extension of the thrombus.
  • Intervention includes embolectomy and intra-arterial thrombolysis.

Option B: Hair loss

  • Integumentary changes like hair loss and hardening of nails are features of chronic limb ischemia due to decrease turnover of keratin.
  • Hair loss is not a feature of acute limb ischemia.
  • Hair loss, known as alopecia, is of three types:
    • Alopecia areata
    • Alopecia Universalis
    • Alopecia totalis

Option C: Cyanosis

  • Cyanosis is bluish discolouration of the skin resulting from poor circulation and inadequate tissue perfusion.
  • When a blood supply to a tissue is blocked, pallor occurs, followed by cyanosis.

Option D: Gangrene

  • Macroscopic death of tissues is known as gangrene due to impaired blood supply and ensuing bacterial invasion.
  • There are three types of gangrene:
    • Dry gangrene
    • Wet gangrene
    • Gas gangrene

questions.text: In a noninflammatory, postmenopausal Pap smear, what percentage of the cells in the maturation index are superficial cells?
questions.solution:
- The maturation index is a measure of percentages of cell layers in cervical and vaginal cytology.
- It is typically written as x/y/z with x as the percentage of parabasal cells, y as the percentage of intermediate cells, and z as the percentage of superficial cells.
- The percentages change under hormonal influence and are not useful in the presence of dysplastic cells.
- In a noninflammatory, postmenopausal Pap smear, none of the cells in the maturation index are superficial cells. (Superficial cells occupy the topmost layer of the epithelium; the nucleus is small and lacks a chromatin pattern.)
- In the absence of extrinsic estrogens or inflammation, the presence of significant numbers of superficial cells is abnormal in the postmenopausal period. The number of superficial cells can increase as a result of infection, vaginal dermatoses, estrogen administration, certain neoplasms, and certain hormonal abnormalities.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presented to the physician's clinic with a complaint of thin whitish vaginal discharge for the past week. On physical examination, the discharge is seen and  vaginal discharge sample is collected, and the examination findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the disease caused by the organism seen around the vaginal cells in the image?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bacterial vaginosis

The patient, as mentioned above, has bacterial vaginosis (BV), with the examination of vaginal discharge showing clue cells.

  • The image depicts a clue cell on microscopy, which are pathognomic of bacterial vaginosis. The clue cells show numerous bacteria obscuring the borders of vaginal epithelial cells, giving them a stippled appearance.
  • Numerous studies show an association of BV with significant adverse sequelae.
  • Women with BV are at increased risk for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), postabortal PID, postoperative cuff infections after hysterectomy, and abnormal cervical cytology. Pregnant women with BV risk premature rupture of the membranes, preterm labour and delivery, chorioamnionitis, and postcesarean endometritis.
  • In women with BV undergoing surgical abortion or hysterectomy, perioperative treatment with metronidazole eliminates this increased risk.
  • It is diagnosed based on the following findings:
  1. Microscopy of vaginal secretions: Reveal clue cells, and leukocytes are conspicuously absent.
  2. Adding KOH to the vaginal secretions (the “whiff” test) releases a fishy, amine-like odour.
  3. Alternative diagnostic tests include pH (> 4.5) and amines test card, detection of G. vaginalis ribosomal RNA, or Gram stain.

 

Option A: Herpes simplex

 

  • The virus infects viable epidermal cells leading to erythema and abscess formation. With cell death and cell wall lysis, blister formation occurs. The covering then disrupts, leaving a usually painful ulcer. Soon these lesions develop crusting and heal.
  • Burning and severe pain accompany initial vesicular lesions. This patient has no such symptoms.
  • Herpes simplex does not form clue cells. The PCR test of the skin lesions is the test of choice. The Tzank test includes a smear of skin vesicles showing multinucleated giant cells. Viral culture shows intranuclear eosinophilic Cowdry A inclusions, as shown in the image above.

 

Option C: Chancroid

  • The chancroid presents initially with an erythematous papule that becomes pustular and ulcerates within 48 hours. Edges of these painful ulcers are usually irregular, with erythematous non-indurated margins. The ulcer bases are usually red and granular, covered with purulent material. Furthermore, they develop unilateral and bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.
  • Diagnosis is made by growth on special media and identification of gram-negative, non-motile rods.

 

Option D: Syphillis

  • Syphilis is caused by spirochetes identified by dark-field examination or direct fluorescent antibody testing of the lesion exudate. Other serology tests include Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) and fluorescent treponemal antibody-absorption (FTA-ABS).
  • The clue cells are not seen in syphilis.

questions.text: A 7 year old child is brought with fever, colicky abdominal pain and non-blanching palpable purpuric rash on buttocks and back of legs. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The combination of fever, extensor palpable purpuric rash and GIT symptoms favour diagnosis of Henoch Schonlein purpura in the child.
  • ITP is ruled out as it has non palpable purpura.
  • Meningococcemia will cause a rash on lower extremities but will not have a predilection for extensor sites.
  • Wegener’s granulomatosis presents with epistaxis, haematuria and haemoptysis.

questions.text: A 6 year old boy was brought by his parents to the clinic, who were anxious about the excessive increase in the size of the boy’s phallus, from the age of 1 ½ years if age. The bone age is 12 years. Which of the following instruments is useful in the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution: An orchidometer is a medical instrument that can be used to accurately measure volume and determine the size of the testicle. The cutout sizes are compared with the testicle of the patient using the volume that matches most closely in size. Pre-pubertal sizes are 1-3 cc, pubertal sizes are considered 4 cc and up and adult sizes are 12-25 cc.

questions.text: Name the following instrument:
questions.solution:
GREEN–ARMYTAGE HEMOSTATIC FORCEPS

This forceps is used in lower segment cesarean section. Total four forceps are ordinarily required— one for each angle and one for each flap. Its functions are hemostasis and to catch hold of the margins so that they are not missed during suture. It cannot be used in classical cesarean section. Alternative to this Allis tissue forceps may be used.

questions.text: A 15 year old boy with complaints of swelling at lower end of left femur, swelling has local local temperature raised, ill defined margins, variable consistency and dilated veins. On X-ray there is bony swelling from lower end of femur and there is Codman’s triangle (Periosteal Reaction) all the following are required for diagnosis EXCEPT:
questions.solution: This looks like a case of malignant bone lesion for which CT ,MRI and bone scan will be essential. But we will need a BIOPSY of the bone to confirm the lesion and not a bone marrow biopsy which is done for marrow disorders.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about electrolytes in colon is correct:

choices.text: Absorption of Na+ in the colon is under hormonal (aldosterone) control
Bile acids enhance absorption of water from the colon
Net absorption of HCO3 - occurs in the colon
Net absorption of K+ occurs in the colon

questions.solution:
• The major route of absorption of sodium in the colon is electrogenic transport. Large potential difference exists between the mucosal (negative) and serosal (positive) surface of the absorptive cells. The electrical difference favours the net secretion of K+ into the lumen
  • The amounts of absorption of Na+ and secretion of K+ can be affected by changes in levels of aldosterone.
  • Secretion of HCO3- occurs in exchange for absorption of Cl-. No counter balancing cation exchange pumps are present in the colon

questions.text: Severe acute malnourishment is defined as-
questions.solution: Severe acute malnutrition is defined as severe wasting and/or bilateral edema. Severe wasting is extreme thinness diagnosed by a weight-for-length (or height) below −3?SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents to the clinic complaining of a lesion in his oral cavity, which looks like a frog’s belly. He is scheduled for elective surgery. During the surgery, the surgeon employs the following instrument. What is the name of this instrument?
questions.solution:
Option C: Doyen’s mouth gag

  • The patient has an intra-oral ranula and is being planned for marsupialization.
  • The above-given image shows a Doyen’s mouth gag.
  • It has blades that are semi-circular and curved at the tip.
  • It is used to keep the mouth open during intra-oral surgeries like
    • Glossectomy
    • Cleft palate
    • Intra-oral ranula

    • To acquire a biopsy from a suspicious lesion

Option A: Joll’s thyroid retractor

  • The Joll’s self-retaining retractor is a speciality surgical tool used for challenging incision sites.
  • It is commonly used for thyroid and vaginal procedures due to its unusual form, which allows it to access these anatomical locations more effectively.

Option B: Morris retractor

  • The Morris Retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall, loin, and subcostal incisions.
  • It can fit a wide range of wounds at any depth.
  • The handle has an oval ring that provides an improved grip for an assistant's fingertips.

Option D: Beckman Weitlaner retractor

  • The Beckman Weitlaner retractor is a surgical instrument used in veterinary surgery to retract tissues and skin.
  • It is most typically utilized in spinal and intracranial procedures.
  • The instrument is equipped with finger ring grips and a self-locking mechanism.

questions.text: When is the second polar body extruded ?
questions.solution:
In the ovary, a single oocyte is formed from the two meiotic divisions of the oogonium, with excess genetic material contained in two polar bodies, each extruded as a result of the one meiotic division.

In the oocyte, LH stimulation results in resumption of meiosis. The diplotene stage leads to diakinesis and prophase I is completed. Oocyte then progresses to metaphase I, anaphase I, and telophase I, and then cell division occurs. The oocyte retains the vast majority of the ooplasm but the chromatin is divided equally between the oocyte and the polar body.Thus, the first polar body is extruded accompanied by ovulation (or just prior to ovulation), while the second polar body is extruded after fertilization of the ovum by the sperm.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presented to opd with complains of sudden onset palpitations and dizziness . He is a k/c/o COPD and developed a viral upper respiratory infection for which he was taking an over-the-counter decongestant. Shortly thereafter he started experiencing palpitations . O/E - Pulse = 150/ min. , Rhytm = regular, BP = 80/60 mm Hg. ECG was done which shows following findings. Likely diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
• ECG reveals saw tooth waves of atrial flutter with variable AV block.

  • Atrial flutter results from an abnormal circuit inside the right atrium, or upper chamber of your heart. It beats extra fast, about 250-400 beats per minute. A normal heartbeat is 60-100 beats per minute.

questions.text: Identify the given image:

An obese male patient who is a known case of diabetes has presented with OPD with increased serum ferritin levels. Upon further investigations, it is found that he is a case of Non- alcoholic fatty liver disease. Which of the following is the most common cause of Non- alcoholic fatty liver disease?
questions.solution:
Option B: Syndrome-X

  • A condition marked by extra fat around the abdomen, high levels of blood glucose (sugar) when not eating, high levels of triglycerides (a type of fat) in the blood, low levels of high-density lipoproteins (a type of protein that carries fats) in the blood, and high blood pressure.
  • Also known as Metabolic syndrome
  • Abnormalities associates Syndrome X:
    • Impaired fasting plasma glucose concentration
    • Impaired glucose tolerance
    • Increase plasma uric acid concentration
    • Decrease renal uric acid concentration
    • Increase plasma triglyceride concentration
    • Increase renal sodium retention
    • Increase blood pressure
    • Polycystic ovary syndrome

Option A: Reye syndrome

  • Reye's syndrome is a very rare disorder that can cause serious liver and brain damage. If it's not treated promptly, it may lead to permanent brain injury or death.
  • Reye's syndrome mainly affects children and young adults under 20 years of age.

Option C: Cardiac syndrome-X

  • Cardiac syndrome X (CSX) is characterized by typical or atypical anginal chest pain with no evidence of significant coronary vascular abnormalities visualized on an angiogram. It is viewed as a type of ischemic heart disease with occurrence most prevalent in perimenopausal and postmenopausal females. To avoid the high morbidity and complications associated with this condition requires prompt diagnosis and treatment. This activity reviews the evaluation and treatment of CSX and highlights the role of the interprofessional team in evaluating and treating patients with this condition

Objectives:

  • Review the pathogenesis of cardiac syndrome X.
  • Describe the treatment modalities of cardiac syndrome X.
  • Identify the complications of cardiac syndrome X.
  • Summarize interprofessional team strategies for improving care coordination and patient education in treating patients with cardiac syndrome X and improving outcomes.

Option D: Pregnancy

  • The 5 pregnancy-related liver disorders—are acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP), HELLP syndrome (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes and low platelets), pre-eclamptic liver dysfunction, intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP) and hyperemesis gravidarum—occur in different gestational time periods. This review focuses on these pregnancy-related liver disorders.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient undergoing an arthroscopic procedure on the right shoulder under general anaesthesia and an interscalene block in the sitting position develops bradycardia and hypotension during the intra-operative period. The interscalene block was performed using 20ml of 1% lidocaine with epinephrine. The most appropriate treatment is:
questions.solution:
Bezold-Jarisch reflex (BJR), a paradoxical activation of the left ventricular mechanoreceptors caused by reduced venous return, due to pooling of blood in the lower extremities in the sitting position. Ephedrine is the drug of choice.

Phenylephrine has predominantly a1 effects causing peripheral vasoconstriction. Metaraminol is also a potent vasoconstrictor. Both phenylephrine and metaraminol will increase blood pressure and can cause reflex bradycardia. Atropine alone is not effective in treating this condition.

questions.text: Which segment of the facial nerve lies near the oval window?
questions.solution: The tympanic/ horizontal segment passes over the oval window and under the lateral semicircular canal and then forms the 2nd genu and becomes the vertical segment/ mastoid segment.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female consults about hormone replacement therapy (HRT). The most compelling indication for starting HRT is:?

choices.text: Control of vasomotor symptoms such as flushing

questions.solution:
• Principal health concerns of menopausal women include vasomotor symptoms, Urogenital atrophy, Osteoporosis, Cognitive decline, and Sexual problems.
  • Vasomotor symptoms affect up to 75% of perimenopausal women. Symptoms last for 1 to 2 years after menopause in most women but may continue for 10 years or longer in others.
  • Treatment of vasomotor symptoms should improve these cognitive and mood symptoms if they are secondary to sleep disruption and its resulting daytime fatigue. The incidence of thyroid disease increases as women age; therefore, thyroid function tests should be performed if vasomotor symptoms are atypical or resistant to therapy. Vasomotor symptoms are a consequence of estrogen withdrawal, not simply estrogen deficiency. Systemic estrogen therapy is the most effective treatment for vasomotor symptoms and the only therapy currently approved.
  • Other methods to reduce symptoms include Clonidine, Selective serotonin, and Norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, Paroxetine Venlafaxine, Gabapentin, Nonprescription medications, Isoflavone supplements, Soy products, Black cohosh, Vitamin E, Lifestyle changes, Reducing body temperature, Reducing obesity.

questions.text: In nuclear cataract , there is discolouration due to urochrome pigments deposited in lens. Choose the correct order of pigmentation.
questions.solution: In nuclear cataract discolouration, the lens becomes yellow → amber → brown(cataracta brunnesense) → black (cataracta nigra). This discolouration helps in grading of nuclear cataract

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is found to have an anterior neck mass. Her thyroid scan, shown below, exhibits findings that are consistent with which of the following disorders?
questions.solution: The thyroid scan ofthe patient discussed in the question shows a discrete area of decreased radioactive iodine uptake with the remainder of the gland accepting iodine normally. This means the tissue that composes the nodule is not endocrino-logically active for thyroid hormone. The two major mass lesions of the thyroid that can produce this pattern are a nonfunctioning follicular ade-noma and a carcinoma. Carcinomas seldom produce thyroid hormone. Adenomas may be very active (toxic) and suppress the remaining gland. Most thyroid adenomas, however, are not hormone producing and appear as “cold” nodules on a thyroid scan. Graves’ disease produces a diffusely hyperactive gland without nodularity. de Quervain’s thyroiditis presents as a painful, swollen thyroid gland rather than as a discrete nodule. A large parathyroid adenoma could conceivably displace the thyroid gland and produce a pattern similar to the one shown, but it would be unusual. A localized infectious process also could produce such a pattern. The essen-tial point is that a “cold” thyroid nodule may represent a carcinoma, and needle biopsy or surgical excision is indicated to rule out this possibility

questions.text: In the resection of a stenotic area of the intestine in a patient with Crohn’s disease, the best approach is:

choices.text: A resection margin of 2 cm from thegross disease.
A resection margin of 12 cm from the gross disease.
A resection margin 2 cm from the microscopic disease on frozen section.
A resection margin 12 cm from the microscopic disease on frozen section.

questions.solution: There are no differences in the recurrence rates for resection with a 2-cm margin or a 12-cm margin from the gross disease. The additional bowel lost may contribute to the eventual short gut syndrome in a patient who requires multiple resections, so minimizing bowel loss is a priority. There is no benefit to achieving frozen section negative margins in the resection of Crohn’s strictures; positive margin resections have the same recurrence rate as negative margin resections. The effort to obtain a frozen section negative margin carries the risk of removing more intestine than is necessary.
